Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: On average, 18- 20 hours per week but it fluctuated depending on what I was doing in lab that week.
I like that it's an immersive lab experience and I learned a lot about a subject that was new to me. Doug Brackney is a great PI and very knowledgeable.

This rotation is very useful. I learned a lot in the rotation include wet lab work and bioinformatic programming. However, if I can have the chance to learn coding work hand in hand by the bioinformatic researcher, that will be much helpful. Or if he can provide me with some learning resource, I can also learn it by myself. By doing that, I will save a great amount of time to do other meaningful stuff.
Dr. Tschudi is great and takes student feedback very seriously.

Professor Tschudi provides me detailed information about how to choose professors to rotate with. He is an amazing instructor. Not only gives you advice on academic life but also daily life. He cares about students a lot. Professor Pettigrew also gives me a lot of opportunities to learn. She supported every decision I made(like what I want to learn in her group) and met with me every Monday morning to give me detailed instruction. I appreciated a lot.
I think all PhD students (even non-EMD) should consider doing at least one rotation. It helps broaden horizons.
Highly recommend. You will get into a specific research group and you will know if you fit with this realm or not, like the instructor or not etc.
